image.altText: A graphic comprised of images of four men in suits. Behind them is an audio wave form.

items.synopsis: As the walls close in on the conspirators behind the massive Plutus tax scam, they have no idea police are listening in on every conversation.

title.children: 'Oh, we're cooked': Australia's biggest tax scam is unravelling. Police are listening to every word

image.altText: A commonwealth bank sign and logo.

items.synopsis: Customers of Australia's largest bank have been unable to access their money or use online banking due to a widespread technical outage.

title.children: 'I cannot use my own money': CommBank customers 'livid' as tech issue crashes banking services

image.altText: Thunderbirds players hug

items.synopsis: A last-minute pitch by South Australia's premier to bring the Super Netball grand final to Adelaide after the Thunderbirds' extraordinary win has fallen flat, with Peter Malinauskas saying the commercial deal was "almost impossible" to unpick.

title.children: SA rebuffed in last-minute bid to bring Super Netball grand final to Thunderbirds' home ground

image.altText: Spillage from a dam at Basket Range leaving debris, rocks and mud everywhere

items.synopsis: A watch-and-act message is in place for a dam at high risk of failure south of Adelaide and a separate warning is in place for a dam in the Adelaide Hills, but crews are confident they will be able to mitigate risks.

title.children: Emergency crews continue to monitor Adelaide dams at risk of failing

image.altText: A sinkhole on a wet path

items.synopsis: After heavy rain, a 2-metre deep sinkhole has appeared in Mount Gambier's CBD. The council is now mapping other areas vulnerable to subsidence to "stay on the front foot".

title.children: 'Huge' sinkhole appears in SA city as rock 'dissolves like sugar'

image.altText: Pwc Logo

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is down in early trade, along with electronic banking for many CBA customers. PwC is accused of "self-centred" motives behind its planned business split. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: PwC accused of 'phoenix' split, customers await answers on CBA outage, ASX slips on miners

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: My CBA e-banking all working at 1300 - David. Some readers say their CBA electronic banking is working, others say it's still down and still others have had access on and off over the morning. Bill 12:54:07 PM Re: the CBA outage. Couldn't get on to Netbank, not the app but through a PC. I have an urgent payment to make, so went to the local branch, where they told me that everything was in chaos and they couldn't access any information to process any payments. ATMs were working off and on, with a $200 limit.  Given the payment I was going to make would save me on interest, and has been delayed, I asked if they could waive the additional interest due to the system outage. Blank looks. Penelope 12:58:38 PM Hi Michael, re the CBA outage confirming at 12:55pm I was able to access my accounts via the app and transfer cash between them. The app can’t display the “simple balance” on the Home Screen but it was fine once I logged in. Commbank Customer 1:01:40 PM my commbank app was showing $0 and no account info all morning but now my balance is back (and my loans unfortunately) Georgia 1:06:19 PM My CommBank app has been intermittently working throughout the day. Currently not working but needed lunch so took a gamble on Maccas to try my card and didn’t seem to have any issues… or I’ve accidentally stolen food. Kate 12:50:36 PM CBA ISSUE I feel the CBA are not being truthful about the issue. I’m not able to process our payroll.. have been able to access payments since 8am today This small sample of feedback seems to corroborate CBA's statement that there are intermittent issues affecting some customers, although it definitely sounds like "some" = "many", perhaps even "most". We wait to hear more from CBA. My colleagues, our national consumer affairs reporter Michael Atkin and Leonie Thorne, are on the case and are updating the story below as they find out more. I'll also keep you up to date in this blog until it closes around 4:30pm AEST.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mixed experiences with CBA outage

featuredLink.title: Commonwealth Bank outage leaves customers unable to access money

children.content: My CBA e-banking all working at 1300
- David
Some readers say their CBA electronic banking is working, others say it's still down and still others have had access on and off over the morning.
Bill

Re: the CBA outage. Couldn't get on to Netbank, not the app but through a PC. I have an urgent payment to make, so went to the local branch, where they told me that everything was in chaos and they couldn't access any information to process any payments. ATMs were working off and on, with a $200 limit.  Given the payment I was going to make would save me on interest, and has been delayed, I asked if they could waive the additional interest due to the system outage. Blank looks.
Penelope

Hi Michael, re the CBA outage confirming at 12:55pm I was able to access my accounts via the app and transfer cash between them. The app can’t display the “simple balance” on the Home Screen but it was fine once I logged in.
Commbank Customer
my commbank app was showing $0 and no account info all morning but now my balance is back (and my loans unfortunately)
Georgia

My CommBank app has been intermittently working throughout the day. Currently not working but needed lunch so took a gamble on Maccas to try my card and didn’t seem to have any issues… or I’ve accidentally stolen food.
Kate
CBA ISSUE I feel the CBA are not being truthful about the issue. I’m not able to process our payroll.. have been able to access payments since 8am today

This small sample of feedback seems to corroborate CBA's statement that there are intermittent issues affecting some customers, although it definitely sounds like "some" = "many", perhaps even "most".
We wait to hear more from CBA
My colleagues, our
national consumer affairs reporter Michael Atkin
and
Leonie Thorne
, are on the case and are updating the story below as they find out more. I'll also keep you up to date in this blog until it closes around 4:30pm AEST.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The latest update from CBA to its customers via its incident website : "We are aware some customers are experiencing intermittent difficulties accessing some of our services and we are urgently working to resolve these issues. "Our call centres and branches are experiencing high volumes of customer enquiries at the moment due to these service issues and there may be longer than usual wait times." The bank is strongly implying that not all customers are affected, but all we are hearing is from those who are. I'd be interested to hear if you are a CBA customer whose electronic banking, EFTPOS, etc… are still working. Send a comment via the button at the top of the page.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA says "some customers" are still experiencing "intermittent difficulties"

children.content: The latest update from CBA to its customers via its
incident
website
"We are aware some customers are experiencing intermittent difficulties accessing some of our services and we are urgently working to resolve these issues.
"Our call centres and branches are experiencing high volumes of customer enquiries at the moment due to these service issues and there may be longer than usual wait times."
The bank is strongly implying that not all customers are affected, but all we are hearing is from those who are.
I'd be interested to hear if you are a CBA customer whose electronic banking, EFTPOS, etc… are still working
Send a comment via the button at the top of the page.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PwC's acting chief executive Kristen Stubbins has told a NSW parliamentary committee that the firm did not become aware that partner Peter-John Collins had signed a confidentiality agreement regarding his work for the federal government on multinational tax avoidance laws until March 2021. Ms Stubbins says PwC has since significantly tightened up its policies and procedures around confidentiality agreements entered into by its partners and staff. If you're a bit lost about what exactly PwC and some of its staff are accused of doing and why there is so much ongoing scrutiny of the consulting and accounting firm, Kate Ainsworth did a comprehensive explainer earlier this month.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC unaware of tax confidentiality agreement until March 2021, acting CEO says

featuredLink.title: At least 53 people knew about the PwC tax leak — so why don't we know who they are?

children.content: PwC's acting chief executive Kristen Stubbins
has told a NSW parliamentary committee that the firm did not become aware that partner
Peter-John Collins
had signed a confidentiality agreement regarding his work for the federal government on multinational tax avoidance laws until March 2021.
Ms Stubbins says PwC has since significantly tightened up its policies and procedures around confidentiality agreements entered into by its partners and staff.
If you're a bit lost about what exactly PwC and some of its staff are accused of doing and why there is so much ongoing scrutiny of the consulting and accounting firm,
Kate Ainsworth did a comprehensive explainer
earlier this month.

image.altText: A composite image of two men. One in a suit, the other in a military flack jacket

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced another military support package for Ukraine worth $110 million.

title.children: Australia commits another $110m to Ukraine's war effort

image.altText: Alexander Lukashenko and Vladimir Putin walking together

items.synopsis: Just a month after he was fighting off poisoning rumours, Alexander Lukashenko stunned almost everyone by saving Vladimir Putin from the brink.

title.children: In his greatest crisis, one man came to Putin's rescue. Here's why everyone is confused

image.altText: A security fence lines an empty block of land.

items.synopsis: The High Court dismisses a bid by Russia to prevent the Commonwealth from taking control of a site it leased for a new embassy.

title.children: High Court throws out Russia's bid to stop Australian government taking control of embassy site

image.altText: APN: Putin Forum

items.synopsis: The prime minister says the aborted mutiny that rattled Russia at the weekend shows the invasion of Ukraine has been a "disaster" for Vladimir Putin.

title.children: Albanese dubs aborted Russian mutiny a 'disaster' for Putin

image.altText: A young woman with long dark hair and face paint

items.synopsis: Police say a 22-year-old woman who was reported missing after a party in rural bushland south-east of Perth has been found safe after she "walked out from the bush".

title.children: Woman reported missing in freezing temperatures after WA 'bush doof' found safe

image.altText: Three women stand in front of a carved wooden sign with their arms crossed.

items.synopsis: Failed lease negotiations between a visiting nurse practitioner and the local council has left the small community of Morgan without an ongoing medical service.

title.children: Rural town faces 'hard slog' after losing regular medical service

image.altText: Simon Crean

items.synopsis: As Labor leader in 2003 Simon Crean called Australia's decision to send troops to Iraq wrong, reckless and unnecessary as he stood up to US president George W Bush.

title.children: Simon Crean never got to lead Labor to an election but he did stand up to a US president

image.altText: young man holds rugby league ball on field

items.synopsis: A 16-year-old "passionate" rugby league player described as having a "big future" in the sport has died after being hit by a car.

title.children: Rugby league young gun remembered after fatal collision

image.altText: A young man on the left wearing a red hoodie, next to him an older man with grey-ish hair, wearing glasses. Both are smiling.

items.synopsis: Christine Dawood says her son Suleman never went anywhere without a Rubik's Cube, and was excited about solving the puzzle "3,700 metres below sea at the Titanic".

title.children: Teen who died in Titanic submersible implosion wanted to break Rubik's Cube world record, mother tells BBC

image.altText: A wide image showing a large crowd in the stands and grounds of an open-roof stadium, many holding one hand in the air

items.synopsis: State media says about 120,000 people took part in the rallies across Pyongyang to mark the 73rd anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean War.

title.children: North Korea vows 'war of revenge' at mass anti-US rallies in Pyongyang

image.altText: adult whale swimming with newborn calf in ocean

items.synopsis: Reports of a possible deceased whale floating near a Coffs Harbour beach have turned out to be a slow-moving mother whale with her newborn calf. The new calf was spotted on ORCCA whale census day, "adding one more additional whale to the tally".

title.children: 'One more to the tally': Whale mother and baby filmed moments after birth on whale census day

image.altText: Two gymnasts wearing Team Australia tops smile at the camera wearing their medals from the Special Olympics.

items.synopsis: With personal bests and medals aplenty, the Australian team finishes on a high at the Special Olympics World Games in Germany.

title.children: Team Australia wins 13 gold medals at Special Olympics World Games

image.altText: An empty apartment with windows looking out over the city to the horizon.

items.synopsis: Around the world, the idea of turning offices underused in the wake of COVID's work-from-home phenomenon into housing is a hot topic. But experts say such projects are few and far between in Australia for a reason, and creating affordable housing from office buildings is harder than it seems.

title.children: Turning underused offices into apartments sounds 'great in theory'. The reality is more complicated

image.altText: A weedy seadragon swims near some seagrass as sunlight filters through to the ocean floor.

items.synopsis: Weedy seadragons attract divers from around the world to Australia's Great Southern Reef, and now, with their help, researchers are uncovering crucial facts about the mysterious creatures.

title.children: How secrets of the weedy seadragon are being revealed by citizen scientists and artificial intelligence

image.altText: A young boy is smiling in a red t-shirt.

items.synopsis: The confidence NSW Police displayed in a breakthrough in the missing person's case dissipated after the boy's foster parents became the focus of homicide investigations.

title.children: On what would have been William Tyrrell's 12th birthday, police remain tight-lipped on one theory

image.altText: Megan Davis standing in front of a bright orange rock, Uluru, with a straight face.

items.synopsis: Megan Davis found an old copy of the Australian Constitution at the back of a book when she was a girl. Thirty years later, she wants to change it to give the Voice to her people.

title.children: She was 12 when she fell in love with the Constitution. Now Megan Davis is giving everything she's got to change it

image.altText: A ute causes a splash as it drives through water on a highway, with a dark sedan pulled over on the side of the road

items.synopsis: Authorities have warned travellers to leave the Gibb River Road today ahead of a likely closure tomorrow, while low-level crossings over the Fitzroy River are also expected to close.

title.children: Travellers urged to reconsider plans as unseasonable rain puts Kimberley on alert

image.altText: Elton John Glastonbury 2023

items.synopsis: More than 200,000 people poured into the UK's Glastonbury Festival over the weekend.

title.children: From Elton John's last UK gig to Cate Blanchett's surprise performance, here's what you missed at Glastonbury 2023

image.altText: Shadowy image of Daryl Maguire, bald and on a profile

items.synopsis: The former Wagga Wagga MP will face court over evidence he gave to ICAC in 2018, where he denied seeking payment for brokering a property deal.

title.children: Gladys Berejiklian's former partner Daryl Maguire faces fresh charge of misleading evidence

image.altText: Shane Barker

items.synopsis: Shane Barker was found dead in his Campbell Town home in 2009 after being shot four times. Fourteen years on, a jury is deciding if a husband and wife were behind the killing.

title.children: A husband and wife stand accused of murdering their son-in-law 14 years ago. Here's the evidence a jury has heard during the trial

image.altText: Clancy Overell and Errol Parker sitting at a desk with newspapers in front of them, one holding a coffee mug, both in Akubras

items.synopsis: It may be a satirical publication, but the impact of The Betoota Advocate is being felt in the tiny outback town that bears its name.

title.children: What happens when you're the mayor of a ghost town and it becomes an international sensation?

image.altText: 11 injured in Hong Kong following Cathay Pacific Incident

items.synopsis: The injuries occurred when passengers exited the aircraft using escape slides after the crew identified "a technical issue".

title.children: Eleven injured as Cathay Pacific flight aborts take-off

image.altText: a woman at a restaurant food pass, looking at a food order

items.synopsis: West End used to be populated by thespians and proletariats, but locals say gentrification has priced them out.

title.children: 'Worst-case scenario, we close': The cost of gentrification for West End's small traders

image.altText: A lady leans on a gate smiling at the Langlo Crossing cemetery

items.synopsis: In outback Queensland, a chance meeting of two women has helped uncover the lost stories of those buried in a ghost town's cemetery, from a baby buried on Christmas Day, to a teen blacksmith who died tragically during a journey to see the doctor.

title.children: Amateur historians help shed light on forgotten past of abandoned cemetery
